Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation2: A major supplier has threatened to halt all future shipments until a significant past-due invoice is settled.
Story:
My phone buzzes insistently as I stare at the spreadsheet, numbers blurring together. It’s Sunday evening—time for my weekly call with Mom and Dad. I know they’re waiting, probably sitting together on the couch, eager to hear about my week and to tell me about the neighbor’s new dog or Dad’s latest gardening project. I promised them I’d never miss these calls, especially since I moved out of state.

But my work phone flashes with a new email: the supplier’s subject line is in all caps, “FINAL NOTICE.” If I don’t resolve this overdue invoice tonight, our production line could grind to a halt tomorrow. My manager expects me to handle it, no excuses. I can already imagine the fallout if I don’t respond immediately.

I glance at my personal phone, then at my work laptop. My parents’ faces float in my mind, their voices warm and expectant. At the same time, the weight of my professional responsibility presses down on me. My heart pounds as I sit at my desk, torn between the comfort of family and the urgency of my job, unable to silence the demands of either.
